elements.content: A metal−organic framework (MOF) based on Pt, Y, and 2,2‘-bipyridine-5,5‘-dicarboxylate (BPDC), stable up to 400 °C, has been synthesized and characterized. In this MOF, the Pt centers are coordinated to Cl and the N atoms of the BPDC unit, giving a local environment similar to that found in a series of Pt−organic complexes with catalytic activity toward C−H bond cleavage of alkanes. This new material is a heterogeneous counterpart to the corresponding metal−organic complex. The structure, determined by single-crystal XRD data, is the repetition of three covalently bonded layers. These layers form a block, which is stacking as an (a)(b)(c) sequence along the crystallographic b-axis. Each layer contains the Pt−organic unit, while Y atoms represent the connection between adjacent layers. No covalent connection is present between layer (a) of a block and layer (c) of an adjacent block. EXAFS (BM29 at the ESRF) analysis supports the XRD data. As this MOF crystallizes under hydrothermal conditions, water acts both as solvent and as a direct ligand of Y. Accessibility to the metal centers is demonstrated by reversible water desorption/readsorption, as determined by TPA/TPD, FTIR, UV−vis, EXAFS, and XANES. Importantly, the results show that the as-synthesized material will not suffer a permanent loss in porosity upon solvent removal. In addition to water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile can also access the internal void of the dehydrated phase.

elements.content: During the past decades, the direct, selective conversion of alkanes into higher valuable products has been subjected to an extensive research effort. About 35 years ago, the first example of alkane activation was reported by Shilov's group. It was then observed that methane activation takes place in an aqueous solution containing K2PtCl4 as catalyst. This so-called Shilov system did, however, suffer from a rather low turn-over number. Later on, a variety of homogeneous catalysts with improved activity and turn-over numbers have been developed using unsaturated electrophilic metal−organic complexes. In particular, complexes with Pt(II) coordinated to nitrogen containing organic ligands by electron donation have been extensively investigated. Although more robust metal−organic complexes have been attained throughout the years, stability still remains a challenge, since their activity toward C−H bonds inevitably leads to a mutual destruction between the complexes. Another challenge addresses the fairly poor thermal stability of the complexes. Moreover, the constantly recurring problem of recovering homogeneous catalysts from the products also motivates the development of heterogeneous counterparts.
elements.clean_text:
1. Introduction

During the past decades, the direct, selective conversion of alkanes into higher valuable products has been subjected to an extensive research effort. About 35 years ago, the first example of alkane activation was reported by Shilov's group. It was then observed that methane activation takes place in an aqueous solution containing K2PtCl4 as catalyst. This so-called Shilov system did, however, suffer from a rather low turn-over number. Later on, a variety of homogeneous catalysts with improved activity and turn-over numbers have been developed using unsaturated electrophilic metal-organic complexes. In particular, complexes with Pt(II) coordinated to nitrogen containing organic ligands by electron donation have been extensively investigated. Although more robust metal-organic complexes have been attained throughout the years, stability still remains a challenge, since their activity toward C-H bonds inevitably leads to a mutual destruction between the complexes. Another challenge addresses the fairly poor thermal stability of the complexes. Moreover, the constantly recurring problem of recovering homogeneous catalysts from the products also motivates the development of heterogeneous counterparts.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a relatively new class of materials. The possibility to control the topology, geometry, and composition of the infinite framework predicts divergent applications. MOF type materials with different physical and chemical properties can indeed be constructed. Materials with possible applications in the fields of molecular separation, gas adsorption, 12 catalysis, sensor technologies, magnetization, luminescence, proton conduction, and semiconduction have already been reported.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a relatively new class of materials. The possibility to control the topology, geometry, and composition of the infinite framework predicts divergent applications. MOF type materials with different physical and chemical properties can indeed be constructed. elements.content: Previously, we presented a controlled procedure for synthesizing a bimetallic MOF with a structure composed of Pt(II) cis-coordinated to Cl and N in 2,2‘-bipyridine-5,5‘-dicarboxylate (BPDC). The Pt−organic part closely resembles the catalytically active sites in homogeneous counterparts developed for C−H activation. In the bimetallic MOF, the Pt−organic parts that constitute the potentially catalytic sites are further connected through Gd ions, resulting in an extended framework (hereafter denoted as Pt/Gd-MOF) stable up to 350 °C. Encouraged by these results, we have extended the development of materials containing the homogeneous counterpart. Herein, we present a new MOF with the same Pt−organic part as previous, but with Y as the corner stone (hereafter denoted as Pt/Y-MOF). Improvement of the thermal stability of the new Pt/Y-MOF from 350 to 400 °C is beneficial for the kinetics and provides higher flexibility in possible catalytic applications. Assuming that the catalytic properties of the above-mentioned homogeneous Pt complexes are due to the atom orientations and that the Pt sites are accessible, the present material may possess properties similar to those of the homogeneous counterparts for the direct conversion of methane.

elements.content: The Pt sites in the present material are now fixed in the rigid lattice, avoiding self-destruction, thermal decomposition at low temperatures (present for the classical homogeneous complexes), and problems related to separating the catalyst from the reaction mixture.

elements.content: As the first step of the heterogenization process, i.e., incorporating Pt(II)−organic units in a self-assembling network, has been accomplished, further characterization has been performed. Prior to designing catalytic test experiments, it is essential to have a fundamental knowledge of the adsorption properties of this new class of materials. A prerequisite for an appreciable catalytic activity also involving the bulk of the crystals is porosity toward the reactant.

elements.content: The structure has been determined by single-crystal XRD data. Here, we present a detailed investigation of the adsorption properties of the synthesized Pt/Y-MOF. Our intention is to show that the internal void of the novel synthesized metal−organic framework is accessible to some probe molecules and to understand how the heterogenization procedure possibly alters the electronic properties of the metal centers. Several characterization techniques such as TPA/TPD, UV−vis, FTIR, and XAS have been applied. The combination of these methods can describe the influence of the probe molecules and follow the changes at the metal atoms.

The combination of these methods can describe the influence of the probe molecules and follow the changes at the metal atoms.

elements.content: 2.1. Synthesis of Pt/Y-MOF. The synthesis of the Pt/Y-MOF was performed under hydrothermal conditions. The chemicals were obtained from Aldrich and used as received. Single crystals were obtained after leaving a mixture of 0.10 g (0.24 mmol) of K2PtCl4, 0.06 g (0.24 mmol) of 2,2‘-bipyridine-5,5‘-dicarboxylic acid, 0.36 g (0.94 mmol) of Y(NO3)3·6H2O, and 8.49 g (0.47 mol) of distilled water in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 12 h. The product was isolated after quenching, filtration, washing with water, and drying in air at ambient temperature. The isolated product was a mixture of Pt/Y-MOF and the unreacted organic ligand. Performing the same synthesis in a microwave oven (Microsynth Ethos 1600) in a Teflon-lined PEEK (polyether-ether-ketone) autoclave with rapid heating (heating rate:  80 °C/min) and continuous magnetic stirring gave a powder of pure Pt/Y-MOF (94.6% yield based on Pt). This material is air and moisture resistant; no loss of crystallinity has been observed after 2 years of storage in air without further protection for air, moisture, and light.
elements.clean_text:
2. Experimental Section

 2.1. Synthesis of Pt/Y-MOF. The synthesis of the Pt/Y-MOF was performed under hydrothermal conditions. The chemicals were obtained from Aldrich and used as received. Single crystals were obtained after leaving a mixture of 0.10 g (0.24 mmol) of K2PtCl4, 0.06 g (0.24 mmol) of 2,2‘-bipyridine-5,5‘-dicarboxylic acid, 0.36 g (0.94 mmol) of Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O, and 8.49 g (0.47 mol) of distilled water in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 12 h. The product was isolated after quenching, filtration, washing with water, and drying in air at ambient temperature. The isolated product was a mixture of Pt/Y-MOF and the unreacted organic ligand. Performing the same synthesis in a microwave oven (Microsynth Ethos 1600) in a Teflon-lined PEEK (polyether-ether-ketone) autoclave with rapid heating (heating rate: 80 °C/min) and continuous magnetic stirring gave a powder of pure Pt/Y-MOF (94.6% yield based on Pt). This material is air and moisture resistant; no loss of crystallinity has been observed after 2 years of storage in air without further protection for air, moisture, and light.

elements.content: 2.2. Structural Methods. The structure was determined from single-crystal XRD by using a Bruker Smart diffractometer equipped with CCD camera, Mo tube, and graphite monochromator (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data collection was performed at 105 K.

elements.content: The crystal structure was solved by direct methods (data collection:  Δω = 0.6°; 2θ = 29°; φ = 0°, 85°, 170°; χ = 54.77°; t = 45 s). The data was integrated in the Saint+ program package; empirical absorption correction was carried out using the program Sadabs and refined in the WinGX program package using the program Shelx-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Due to the large scattering from platinum compared to that of the lighter neighbor atoms (C and N), these atoms were refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms connected to the aromatic part were placed in the calculated positions and refined as a rigid model with isotropic displacement parameters. Scattering from hydrogen in water was ignored. The crystallographic parameters are listed in Table . Elemental analysis, confirming the bulk composition, was performed by the Ilse Beetz Mikroanalytisches Laboratorium (Germany).

Temperature-resolved XRPD data were recorded on a Siemens D500 instrument equipped with Cu X-ray tube combined with a β-filter. The experiment was performed in a Bühler furnace, allowing customized temperature programming and atmosphere control. The sample was smeared on a Pt filament, and data were collected in steps of 50 °C in the temperature range of 50−900 °C in N2 flow.

elements.content: 2.3. Thermal Methods. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and temperature-controlled adsorption/desorption (TPA/TPD) were carried out in a Rheometric Scientific STA1500 instrument. Around 10 mg was placed in an Al2O3 crucible. The TGA profile of the sample was obtained by heating it from ambient temperature to 700 °C (heating rate 2 °C/min with continuous N2 flow).

elements.content: In the TPA/TPD experiments, the water in the structure was removed by heating the sample to 185 °C (heating rate 10 °C/min) in N2 flow. After cooling to room temperature (RT), the carrier gas (N2) saturated with the probe molecules (water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile) was admitted to the sample. When the weight was stabilized, the sample was reheated to 185 °C (heating rate 10 °C/min). The total gas flow (25 mL/min) was nearly constant during the experiment. The probe molecules were obtained commercially (purity 99.9%) without further purifications except that freshly calcined molecular sieve (3A) was added (except in the case with distilled water) to avoid water contamination in the solutions.

elements.content: 2.4. FT-IR and UV − Vis DRS Spectroscopies. The IR spectra were collected at 2 cm-1 resolution with a Bruker IFS66 spectrophotometer equipped with an MCT detector. A water slurry of the sample was applied on a Si wafer. After having desorbed excess water, the Si wafer coated with the MOF was mounted in the quartz/KBr IR cell. A vacuum line permanently attached to the cell enabled in situ outgassing and controlled dosage of probe molecules. All spectra were recorded at ambient temperature.

elements.content: UV−vis DRS spectra were recorded at RT on a Perkin-Elmer λ19 spectrophotometer in the range of 52 000−4000 cm-1. The sample was diluted with calcined BaSO4 and compressed into a self-supporting wafer and mounted in an all-quartz cell. A vacuum line permanently connected to the cell enabled in situ evacuation of water at RT.

elements.content: 2.5. XANES and EXAFS Spectroscopies and Related Data Analysis. X-ray absorption experiments on the Pt L3-edge and Y K-edge were performed at the BM29 beamline at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF). The monochromator was constituted of two Si(311) flat crystals, and harmonic rejection was achieved by Rh-coated mirrors after the monochromator. Simultaneous to the sample acquisition a Pt foil (or a Y standard), located behind the sample, was recorded in order to calibrate the energy of each spectrum. For the XANES part, a sampling step of 0.3 eV was applied, while for the EXAFS parts a constant sampling step in k-space (Δk = 0.025 Å-1) was used. The integration time was 3 s per step. Spectra were collected in the 16 750−18 560 eV and 11 080−13 850 eV ranges for Y K- and Pt L3-edges, respectively. All spectra were collected at RT using a metallic cell allowing in situ high-temperature treatments and gas dosage. The samples were compressed into self-supporting wafers. To obtain a reliable comparison, not influenced by possible different sample preparations, all wafers have been measured on both edges after each thermal or chemical treatment. As a consequence, the ionization chamber and pellets thickness were optimized to an intermediate value between the ideal one for each single edge.

elements.content: EXAFS analysis was extracted using Klementev's programs. Phase and amplitude were calculated by the FEFF 8.20 code37b using as input the structures of the (2,2‘-bipyridyl)-dichloro-Pt(II) complex38 and Y2O3. Pt−Cl phases and amplitudes have been successfully checked with PtCl2 model compounds.

elements.content: The analysis of the EXAFS signals were performed on back Fourier-filtered signals. For the Pt L3-edge we have adopted a k-window from 1.50 to 19.80 Å-1, with a k 3 weight, and an R window of 1.00−2.80 Å:  2ΔkΔR/π = 20.9. For the Y K-edge, we have used a k-window from 2.3 to 12.00 Å-1, with a k 3 weight, and an R window of 0.72−2.38 Å:  2ΔkΔR/π = 10.3.

a  For atom labeling refer to Figure .

A simplified illustration of the structure is given in Figure . Obviously, Pt retains the preferred square planar hybridization in the lattice and is cis-coordinated to two Cl and the two N atoms in BPDC. The extended lattice is formed by connecting these Pt−organic units through Y. There are three Pt and two Y atoms in the asymmetric unit shown in Figure . Two of the Pt−organic units (Pt1 and Pt3) have all the four O atoms engaged in a direct coordination to Y. The remaining Pt−organic unit (Pt2) is using only one O atom of the carboxylate for coordination (Figure ). This Pt/Y-MOF is a layered structure formed by the repetition of three covalently bonded layers constituted by the Pt−organic units, labeled as layers (a), (b), and (c) in Figure . These layers form a block and is stacking as an (a)(b)(c) sequence along the crystallographic b-axis. No covalent connection is present between layer (a) of a block and layer (c) of an adjacent block. The Pt/Y-MOF is isostructural with the previous Pt/Gd-MOF designed for the same purposes.
elements.clean_text: A simplified illustration of the structure is given in Figure . Obviously, Pt retains the preferred square planar hybridization in the lattice and is cis-coordinated to two Cl and the two N atoms in BPDC. The extended lattice is formed by connecting these Pt-organic units through Y. There are three Pt and two Y atoms in the asymmetric unit shown in Figure . Two of the  Pt-organic units (Pt1 and Pt3) have all the four O atoms engaged in a direct coordination to Y. The remaining Pt-organic unit (Pt2) is using only one O atom of the carboxylate for coordination (Figure ). This Pt/Y-MOF is a layered structure formed by the repetition of three covalently bonded layers constituted by the Pt-organic units, labeled as layers (a), (b), and (c) in Figure . These layers form a block and is stacking as an (a)(b)(c) sequence along the crystallographic b-axis. No covalent connection is present between layer (a) of a block and layer (c) of an adjacent block. The Pt/Y-MOF is isostructural with the previous Pt/Gd-MOF designed for the same purposes.

elements.content: 3.2. Pt and Y Local Structures in As-Synthesized Pt/Y-MOF by EXAFS. To complement the single-crystal XRD study of this rather intricate system, the local structure of both Pt and Y has been investigated by EXAFS. The black solid lines in Figure represent the experimental k 3χ(k) functions of the as synthesized Pt/Y-MOF at the Pt L3- (top) and at the Y K-edges (bottom). The difference in the data quality is striking:  well-defined oscillations can be observed up to k = 18 Å-1 in the case of the Pt L3-edge, whereas already at k = 10 Å-1 the noise overshadows the signal of the Y K-edge data. Three main reasons can explain this strong difference:  (i) Y has only oxygen atoms in its first coordination sphere, that, owing to their low backscattering power (eight electrons), are associated with an amplitude function that rapidly decreases for high k values, whereas Pt is coordinated to two Cl (17 electrons) which contribution dominates the high k-region of the EXAFS spectrum. (ii) The three unequivalent Pt atoms exhibit a very small dispersion of the first-shell distances:  the Pt−N bonds lie in the 2.016−2.037 Å range (average 2.02(2) Å) and the Pt−Cl ones in the 2.299−2.313 Å range (average 2.308(7) Å). Conversely, the two unequivalent Y atoms have O ligands spread in the 2.225−2.492 Å range (average 2.36(3) Å), see Table . Thus, EXAFS signals coming from the three unequivalent Pt atoms add constructively up to high k-values, whereas those from the Y atoms go rapidly out of phase, resulting in a destructive interference42,43 already at k = π/(2 ΔR) = 5.8 Å-1 for the two extreme distances. (iii) Also, the nature of the bonds involving the two metal atoms plays a role. Pt forms strong chemical bonds, with a significant covalent character, with Cl species and with N atoms of the BPDC unit, whereas the charge-balancing role of Y3+ implies that the Y−O bonds are mainly of electrostatic nature (with five oxygen of the carboxylate units) or of polarizing nature (with the three coordinated water molecules). In both cases the bonds are characterized by long Y−O distances and large Debye−Waller factors.

elements.content: For the Pt data, after having evaluated the relative amplitudes of all scattering paths characterized by a path length (forth and back) smaller than 6.1 Å (corresponding to bond distances up to 3.05 Å), only the single scattering Pt−N, Pt−Cl, and Pt−C paths have been included in the fit. Owing to the small dispersion of the first-shell Pt−N (2.016−2.037 Å) and Pt−Cl (2.299−2.313 Å range) distances, a single Pt−N and a single Pt−Cl contribution have been used. The high R signal has been optimized with two different Pt−C contributions:  one for the closer C-2-carbon from the bipyridine ring, around 2.9 Å and one for the C-6-carbon, around 3.0 Å, away from Pt. The quality of the fit in k-space is excellent (Figure , second from top), as well as the agreement with the single-crystal XRD data (Table first four rows):  R Pt - N = 2.00 ± 0.01 Å (vs 2.02(2) Å); N Pt - N = 2.0 ± 0.2 (vs 2); R Pt - Cl = 2.30 ± 0.01 Å (vs 2.308(7) Å); N Pt - Cl = 2.3 ± 0.2 (vs 2); R Pt-C - 2 = 2.86 ± 0.03 Å (vs 2.87(3) Å); N Pt-C - 2 = 2.9 ± 0.4 (vs 2); R Pt-C - 6 = 2.99 ± 0.04 Å (vs 3.01(3) Å); N Pt - C6 = 3.0 ± 0.4 (vs 2). With the only exception of the two coordination numbers corresponding to the two families of Pt−C distances (that have been largely overestimated by EXAFS), all the remaining structural parameters optimized in the EXAFS data analysis agree well with those obtained from single-crystal XRD.

Summary of the Optimized First-Shell Parameters Obtained from the EXAFS Data Analysis of the As-Prepared Pt/Y-MOF at Both the Pt L3- and the Y K-Edges a

a  In the former case the experimental signal has been optimized including a Pt−N, a Pt−Cl, and two Pt−C contributions (the C-2-carbon and C-6-carbon in the 2,2‘-bipyridine ring). The reported values are averaged over the three crystallographically independent Pt sites (Figures and ). The rather low distribution of distances in the three Pt sites (Table ) results in a high-quality fit (Figure , second from top). The experimental signal of the Y K-edge has been optimized using a unique Y−O contribution. All corresponding parameters consequently have an average character. The large values of the optimized Debye−Waller factor reflect the heterogeneities of the Y−O distances (in the 2.225−2.492 Å range, see Table ) and have no dynamical meaning. The parameters that have been fixed in the fit have no corresponding error bars.

Owing to the smaller available k-range and to the lower signal-to-noise ratio (Figure , third from top), a much simpler analysis has been performed for the Y K-edge EXAFS data. The overall EXAFS signal has been optimized using a unique Y−O contribution. All corresponding parameters consequently have an average character. The quality of the fit (Figure , first from bottom) is poorer than that obtained on the Pt L3-edge data; in particular, the single-shell fit cannot account for the experimental signal in the 10−12 Å-1 k-interval. Coming to the numerical outputs of the fit (Table , last row), the number of O ligands is well reproduced:  N Y - O = 8.1 ± 1.0 (vs 8), while the average bond distance obtained from EXAFS is rather contracted with respect to the average of the crystallographic distances:  R Y - O = 2.32 ± 0.03 Å (vs 2.36(3) Å). The apparent shortening of the average Y−O bond length can be explained in terms of bond length heterogeneity. The effect of a large heterogeneity is equivalent to that of a system having an asymmetrical radial distribution function, which can lead to an apparent contraction of bond length in the usual analysis of EXAFS data. This interpretation is supported by the large value of the Debye−Waller factor reflecting Y−O distances (in the 2.225−2.492 Å range, see Table ). Of course this σ2 value has no dynamical meaning.

elements.content: The thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF in N2 was followed by TGA, and the profile is presented in Figure . Besides a weight loss of 9.41 wt % in the first one-hundred degrees, we observe a wide plateau ranging up to 450 °C. This weight loss matches closely the number of 11 water molecules, corresponding to a weight percent of 10.43, refined in the single-crystal XRD study (section 3.1). The chemical nature of the desorbed molecules was checked in a parallel experiment, where we analyzed the effluent as a function of temperature finding that the first weight loss represents water desorption. Temperature-resolved XRPD confirmed the presence of a crystalline phase in the 110−400 °C plateau, see the black patterns in Figure . Combined XRPD and TGA reveal that the crystalline phase is stable up to 400 °C, while an amorphization process occurs in the 400−450 °C range without decomposition, that starts from 450 °C. The improved thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF compared to that of the Pt/Gd-MOF analogue22 (400 vs 350 °C) represents an advantage for any possible application of the material.
elements.clean_text:
4. Thermal Stability Examined by TGA and XRPD

The thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF in N2 was followed by TGA, and the profile is presented in Figure . Besides a weight loss of 9.41 wt % in the first one-hundred degrees, we observe a wide plateau ranging up to 450 °C. This weight loss matches closely the number of 11 water molecules, corresponding to a weight percent of 10.43, refined in the single-crystal XRD study (section 3.1). The chemical nature of the desorbed molecules was checked in a parallel experiment, where we analyzed the effluent as a function of temperature finding that the first weight loss represents water desorption. Temperature-resolved XRPD confirmed the presence of a crystalline phase in the 110-400 °C plateau, see the black patterns in Figure . Combined XRPD and TGA reveal that the crystalline phase is stable up to 400 °C, while an amorphization process occurs in the 400-450 °C range without decomposition, that starts from 450 °C. The improved thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF  compared to that of the Pt/Gd-MOF analogue22 (400 vs 350 °C) represents an advantage for any possible application of the material.

elements.content: For a potential heterogeneous catalyst, reactant diffusivity after solvent removal is indeed a prerequisite for obtaining an optimal activity. Water, alcohols and acetonitrile have been used as probe molecules to investigate the diffusivity and the adsorption/desorption capabilities of the Pt/Y-MOF. The choice of water is obvious as it is the solvent used in the synthesis. Alcohols and acetonitrile have also been selected to monitor the interaction with Brønsted and Lewis acidic centers, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
5. Sample Adsorption/Desorption Capabilities

For a potential heterogeneous catalyst, reactant diffusivity after solvent removal is indeed a prerequisite for obtaining an optimal activity. Water, alcohols and acetonitrile have been used as probe molecules to investigate the diffusivity and the adsorption/desorption capabilities of the Pt/Y-MOF. The choice of water is obvious as it is the solvent used in the synthesis. Alcohols and acetonitrile have also been selected to monitor the interaction with Brønsted and Lewis acidic centers, respectively.

elements.content:
5.1. TPA/TPD. Figure reports the temperature and weight change profiles for adsorbed/desorbed water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile, in parts a−d, respectively.

In each case the experiments have been performed in three steps, as indicated in Figure by the labels “1”, “2”, and “3” on top of each part. Step 1 represents the drying of an as-prepared material performed by heating (10 °C/min) to 185 °C followed by an isothermal period of ≈15 min before cooling down to 25 °C. According to the combined TGA and temperature-resolved XRPD experiment (section 4) the adopted conditions remove adsorbed water without losing the crystallinity. In the four cases, the weight loss of 9.5 wt % during step 1 is consistent with the value reported in the TGA experiment (Figure ). The probe molecules were dosed at 25 °C, defining the start of step 2. Step 2 ends when the weight has stabilized. This equilibrium is readily attained for CH3OH and for CH3CN (less than 10 min), while longer times are required for C2H5OH (≈100 min) and H2O (more than 200 min). Step 3 represents the final heating to 185 °C and leads to a complete desorption in all cases, verifying a fully reversible adsorption. The samples remained crystalline after the TPA/TPD experiments.

elements.content: Similar to the isostructural compound based on Gd as corner stones, the mass of the sample was regained by 98.2% after drying and water readsorption (Figure a). This gives a clear indication that the sample can be fully dehydrated without suffering any permanent loss in porosity. A complete readsorption of water is rather slow under the given conditions. This behavior suggests that once some water molecules have reached the surface, a film may be formed and block the pore openings. That may explain the first and relative quick adsorption of water. A completely readsorption is taking place after water diffusion into the structure. This process can be time-consuming and may correspond to the second and slow adsorption of the TG pattern.

elements.content: To verify that the nano void of the Pt/Y-MOF is accessible, a broader selection of probe molecules with different sizes and polarities were adsorbed after dehydration. Methanol adsorption occurs immediately, and the system reaches equilibrium after few minutes of exposure (Figure b). Ethanol adsorption is rather slow (Figure c) compared to that of methanol adsorption. Ethanol is most likely subjected to severe steric constraints, and a relatively slow diffusion will then impede the process. The adsorption behavior of acetonitrile (Figure d) is similar to methanol. Again, the adsorption occurs immediately and a stable weight was established after few minutes.

elements.content: The quantities of the adsorbed species during step 2 are summarized in Table as molAdsorbate. The equivalent volume occupied by the different probe molecules inside of the porous material is estimated from their density in liquid phase ρ as V Adsorbate = molAdsorbate M Adsorbate/ρ, M Adsorbate being the molar mass of the adsorbed molecule. Performing the same calculations for the amount of desorbed water during step 1, the relative recovered volume in the structure can be estimated by comparing the volume occupied by desorbed crystal water and the volume occupied by the readsorbed species, see the last column in Table . The calculated volume can be underestimated because the molecules adsorbed in the structure will probably not orientate as close as their liquid phases. However, the tendency is quite clear. Physically small probe molecules fill the internal void more efficiently. There is a deviation in the case with ethanol and acetonitrile. This can be explained as ethanol is a molecule containing only single bonds and allows some deformations while acetonitrile has a triple bond which will reduce the flexibility and possibility to pack in a fixed void.

Summary of the Quantitative Data Extracted from the TPA/TPD Experiments Reported in Figure a

probe molecules molDesWater (mmol) molAdsorbate (mmol) ρ (g/cm3) V DesWater (10-4 cm3) V Adsorbate (10-4 cm3) V Adsorbate/V DesWater (%) water 0.050 0.046 0.995 9.0 8.3 92 methanol 0.049 0.015 0.791 8.8 6.1 69 ethanol 0.058 0.011 0.789 10.5 6.4 61 acetonitrile 0.065 0.013 0.786 11.8 6.8 58

a  Amount of desorbed water during the solvent removal process (step 1), molDesWater; amount of adsorbed molecule during step 2, molAdsorbate; density of the probes in their liquid phases, ρ; volume occupied by the desorbed water during step 1, V DesWater; volume occupied by the adsorbed molecule during step 2, V Adsorbate; fraction of recovered volume, V Adsorbate/V DesWater. Adsorbate = water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile.

An evaluation of the surface area of the material has been attempted by the classical of N2 adsorption at 77 K. The obtained adsorption capacity is surprisingly low. However, this experiment was carried out at the boiling point of the applied probe molecule and cannot be comparable with the previous experiments. N2 is nonpolar and can only form weak intramolecular interactions with the lattice that are not able to perform the swelling of the pores needed to allow the molecular penetration inside the MOF. As a consequence, the surface area measured via N2 adsorption probes the external surface only. Conversely, polar molecules are able to condense easily giving rise to a liquidlike phase that, forming a penetration front, is able to exploit the flexibility of the lattice (vide infra sections 5.3 and 5.4).

elements.content: 5.2. DR UV − Vis − NIR Spectroscopy. The UV−vis spectrum of as-prepared Pt/Y-MOF sample (bold black curve in Figure a) is dominated by a band centered at 29 200 cm-1, caused by the intense π → π* transition of the aromatic rings. A relatively broad band located at 25 300 cm-1 can be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) from Pt to bipyridine. The edge in the visible region (at 19 100 cm-1) can be associated to Cl to Pt ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Electronic transitions related to Y are expected at higher energies, where the spectra have not been reported owing to a too poor S/N ratio.

elements.content: Room temperature dehydration process of Pt/Y-MOF followed by UV−vis−NIR DRS spectroscopy:  as-synthesized material (bold black curve), after increasing dehydration times (thin solid curves) up to 4 h (dotted curve) in dynamical vacuum of 10-3 torr. The spectrum obtained after rehydration is reported as a full gray curve. According to the TPA experiment of water readsorption into Pt/Y-MOF (region 2 of Figure a), the gray spectrum has been collected 4 h after water contact. Parts a and b refer to the UV−vis and NIR regions of the spectra, respectively. In the inset of part a, only the spectra of the original, the fully dehydrated, and the rehydrated Pt/Y-MOF have been reported to better appreciate the reversibility of the process.

elements.content: The progressive dehydration of the Pt/Y-MOF was followed by UV−vis−NIR and is reported in Figure (thin black curves). The spectra were collected at RT in a dynamical vacuum of 10-3 torr for increasing times, up to 4 h (dotted spectrum). With the only exception of the Cl to Pt LMCT edge, that red-shifts down to 17 600 cm-1, all the remaining transitions are virtually unaffected by the dehydration process (Figure a). The observed red-shift can be explained by the increased electron density on Cl as a result of water removal, making the electron transfer to Pt easier (red-shift). Note that the phenomenon occurs even if no water molecules are directly bonded to Cl atoms (see Figure ). The distance between Cl and O in uncoordinated water, d(Cl1−O1W) = 3.26 Å, d(Cl1−O2W) = 3.31 Å, d(Cl4−O5W) = 3.29 Å, and d(Cl6−O5W) = 3.29 Å determined from the single-crystal XRD study (section 3.1 and Figure ), concur with previous reports and are compatible with such partial electron density transfer.

elements.content: Another modification of the spectra occurs in the NIR (near infrared) region, Figure b. The overtone and combination modes of the framework vibrational modes (components at 4375, 4575, 4670, and 6050 cm-1) are strongly affected by water desorption showing both shifts and intensity variations. This behavior reflects what observed with IR for the fundamental modes in the 1600−1300 cm-1 region (vide infra section 5.3). The water content in the sample can be followed by the bands at 6950 and 5150 cm-1 in the NIR region (Figure b). These bands represent the overtone of the O−H stretching mode (2νO - H) and the combination of the stretching and bending mode (νO - H + δO - H), respectively. Both bands are decreasing in intensity during removal of water. After 4 h of outgassing (dotted spectrum), the stretching mode (6950 cm-1) almost disappears, showing that the sample is dehydrated. The second band (5150 cm-1) is much less reduced, probably because of the presence of a component due to the lattice vibration of the quartz cell. The other bands are unaffected of the presence of water.

elements.content: The UV−vis−NIR spectrum after readsorption of water (gray curve) shows that all electronic transitions and vibration features are virtually undistinguishable from the as-synthesized sample (bold black curve). The material recovery can be better appreciated in the inset of Figure a where only the spectra of the original (bold black curve), the most dehydrated (dotted curve) and the rehydrated sample (gray curve) have been reported.

elements.content: 5.3. IR Spectroscopy. 5.3.1. Water Adsorption. Figure reports a series of IR spectra of the Pt/Y-MOF with decreasing water content (obtained by evacuation at RT) in the order of red, green, and blue curves. The as-synthesized sample is represented by the bold black spectrum, whereas the gray spectrum was obtained after rehydration. The left part of the figure reports the OH stretching region, while the right part refers to the framework stretching modes and to the bending mode of water.

elements.content: In the high-frequency region, the spectrum of the as-synthesized sample (bold black curve) is dominated by an intense and unresolved absorption extending from 3670 to 3000 cm-1. This band arises from ν(O−H) stretching modes of water contained within the nanopores of the material. At lower frequencies, the spectrum shows an intense band centered at 1660 cm-1, resulting from δ(OH) bending vibrations of water. Furthermore, a multiplet representing the combination modes of carboxylic species mixed with bands from bipyridine ring deformations is located at the low-frequency region of the spectrum. The organic part is characterized by an intense component at about 1590 cm-1 and a doublet at about 1460 and 1370 cm-1. The carboxylic groups are expected to give rather intense bands from asymmetric (1630−1500 cm-1) and symmetric (1460−1350 cm-1) vibrational modes. The highly complex structure of the framework leads to multiplets rather than doublets, and it is difficult to differentiate the contributions of the carboxylic species from those of the bipyridine groups. An exception may be the intense peak at 1583 cm-1 which can be assigned to bipyridine.

elements.content: Water molecules located within the nanopores of the solid are clearly engaged in medium-strong hydrogen bonds, since the O−H stretching and bending modes are red-shifted and blue-shifted, respectively. Water is easily removed from this material at RT by gradually reducing the pressure in the cell. In the high-frequency region, the band representing the ν(O−H) modes declines rapidly upon outgassing. For intermediate water coverages (red and green spectra), a band at 3650 cm-1, representing virtually unperturbed ν(O−H) vibrations in free water molecules, appears. The final spectrum (blue curve) confirms a nearly complete water removal. In comparison to the DRS UV−vis experiment, the rather thin deposition used in the IR experiment gives a significantly faster dehydration. In the region previously dominated by ν(O−H) absorptions, only bands arising from ν(CH) vibrations of the aromatic ligands can be observed.

elements.content: The spectral changes occurring in the low-frequency region are characterized by a higher degree of complexity. A progressive decline in the water bending absorptions is seen. The unresolved band at 1660 cm-1 separates into two distinct components at 1663 and 1645 cm-1 (red spectrum), representing H-bonded and nearly free water molecules, respectively. The band at lower frequency is rapidly eroded, whereas the component at 1663 cm-1 requires a longer outgassing before disappearing. The higher frequency of the most persistent band indicates that part of the water molecules are perturbed by some acidic surface Lewis centers. No evidence of “liquidlike” water, which δ(OH) is expected around 1700 cm-1, is observed.

elements.content: In the region associated with the framework modes, both the positions and the intensity ratios of the maxima changes. The most pronounced modifications can be summarized as follows:  (i) the component at 1614 cm-1 progressively decrease in intensity, (ii) the complex doublets centered at 1583 and 1550 cm-1 shows a very intricate evolution, (iii) the weak doublet at 1505 and 1479 cm-1 increases in intensity, and (iv) doublet with maxima at 1413 and 1386 cm-1 undergoes a substantial intensification. All these features can be rationalized by considering that H2O, being close to the first coordination sphere of Y (section 3.1), strongly perturbs coupled modes of carboxylic species. The main component that could be associated with the bipyridine ring modes (band at 1583 cm-1) does not seem to be appreciably perturbed.

elements.content: In this context, an important point is the reversibility of the water adsorption. To clarify this point, the dehydrated sample was left in contact with a vapor pressure of water at RT for 4 h (gray curve in Figure ; intermediate spectra have been omitted for the sake of clarity). Upon water readsorption, the highly intense and broad absorption of H-bonded water in the ν(O−H) stretching region is clearly restored. Also in the 1700−1300 cm-1 range most of the vibrational properties of the hydrated as-synthesized sample are regained (compare with the black bold curve). More complex is the evolution in the δ(O−H) vibrations of H-bonded water at 1660 cm-1. This mode is now represented as a shoulder of the band at 1615 cm-1. By increasing the water content in the cell, a new component at 1690 cm-1 appears. This band is caused by presence of condensed water on the external surface56 and can easily be removed by evacuation.

elements.content: 5.3.2. Methanol Adsorption. The adsorptive properties of the material have also been investigated using methanol as a probe. Methanol may act both as a proton and electron donor. As a proton donor, an elongation of the O−H bond and a shortening of the C−O bond are expected. Conversely, if methanol acts as an electron donor a small change in the O−H bond and a lengthening of the C−O bond are the outcomes. These properties make the results obtained from CH3OH adsorption particularly interesting.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of methanol adsorbed on the dehydrated Pt/Y-MOF material (bold black curve) are reported in Figure up to an equilibrium pressure of 15 torr (bold gray curve). Intermediate spectra were collected at increasing CH3OH equilibrium pressures. In compliance with the TPA/TPD experiment, methanol adsorption proceeds easily (Figure ), and after a few minutes no spectroscopic changes could be observed. At this stage, we have the presence of a condensed phase inside the metal−organic framework in addition to a small gas-phase contribution. This last contribution is confirmed by the rotovibrational transition at 1033 cm-1 in the ν(C−O) region (right side).

The left part refers to the O−H and C−H stretching region, the right part to the C−O one. The inset reports the framework stretching modes.

elements.content: The two broad bands centered at 3480 and 3260 cm-1 originating from H-bonded species show a different evolution upon increasing the equilibrium pressure, the low-frequency component being formed first. This confirms the presence of at least two kinds of methanol interactions.

elements.content: Also in the ν(C−O) spectral region some interesting spectroscopic changes should be mentioned. The appearance of two distinct maxima at 1012 and 1003 cm-1, due to CH3OH adsorbed species, can be observed together with the gas-phase contribution at 1033 cm-1. The red-shift suggests that methanol is slightly perturbed by two families of Lewis sites. It is well-known that, when methanol is acting as a proton donor, a blue- shift of the ν(C−O) band is expected. This interpretation is supported by the parallel decrease in intensity of the component at 3480 cm-1, easily explained in terms of slightly perturbed ν(OH) modes of methanol interacting with Lewis sites. The presence of Lewis sites in the dehydrated sample can be explained by the Pt−organic units being linked via Y ions. Owing to its large diameter, Y has some H2O molecules in its first coordination sphere that, upon evacuation, leave Y unsaturated, vide infra the EXAFS study in section 5.4. This allows Y to behave as a Lewis acid center. In conclusion, methanol is easily adsorbed on this material forming H-bonded chains and, at high coverages, is slightly perturbed by uncoordinated Y Lewis sites. Evacuation at RT down to 10-3 torr for 50 min (series of spectra not reported for brevity) is sufficient to restore the original spectrum.

elements.content: The ν(C−H) modes of the bipyridine ring (already present on the background spectrum, bold black curve) and the ν(C−H) modes of the methyl group in methanol are present as superimposed contributions on the H-bonded ν(O−H) bands. Finally, we observe that in the region covering the framework vibrations (1700−1300 cm-1) the spectra are nearly unaffected by methanol adsorption (see the inset of Figure ). This strongly suggests that methanol does not interact with both the carboxylic and bipyridine rings and that the main feature is the formation of a pseudoliquid phase (presence of a complex absorption in the ν(O−H) region ascribed to H-bonded methanol).

elements.content: 5.3.3. Deuterated Acetonitrile Adsorption. Acetonitrile is a moderately small molecule which can be admitted in porous materials. The lone pair on nitrogen may acts as Lewis base. Depending on the strength of the electron accepting sites, the C⋮N stretching mode will be influenced. Thus, acetonitrile can be used to probe and classify both Lewis and Brønsted surface sites. In the IR experiments, CD3CN has been used instead of CH3CN in order to avoid the well-known spectroscopic complication due to Fermi resonance between the ν(C⋮N) vibration and the combination mode δ(CH3) + ν(CC).

elements.content: An amount of 10 torr of CD3CN was introduced into the cell containing a wafer of the dehydrated sample, and a series of spectra was subsequently collected as a function of contact time. Figure reports the thus obtained background-subtracted spectra in the ν(C⋮N) stretching region. Spectrum 1 was recorded immediately after CD3CN adsorption, while last spectrum (spectrum 12) was obtained after 80 min. By increasing the contact time the growth of the doublet at 2290 and 2263 cm-1 can be observed. The component at 2263 cm-1 results from physisorbed CD3CN, while the band at 2290 cm-1 is assigned to a perturbed state of CD3CN.

elements.content: In compliance to the observations made with methanol, it is reasonable to believe that the Lewis acid sites formed during evacuation are responsible for the perturbation of the probe molecule also in this case. The blue-shift (Δν = +27 cm-1) indicates that Y acts as a Lewis acid site weaker than both Ti(IV)65 (Δν = +37 cm-1) and uncoordinated Al(III)64 (Δν = +50 cm-1). The band at 2290 cm-1 seems to have a shoulder around 2281 cm-1. The ratio between these two bands is nearly constant for the whole series. The shoulder can then be assigned to a different Lewis site indicating that acetonitrile may interact with Y in different ways. The adsorbed acetonitrile remains in the structure after outgassing at RT. A complete desorption can be obtained by heating to 80 °C.
elements.clean_text: In compliance to the observations made with methanol, it is reasonable to believe that the Lewis acid sites formed during evacuation are responsible for the perturbation of the probe molecule also in this case. The blue-shift (Δν = +27 cm-1)  indicates that Y acts as a Lewis acid site weaker than both Ti(IV)65 (Δν = +37 cm-1) and uncoordinated Al(III)64 (Δν = +50 cm-1). The band at 2290 cm-1 seems to have a shoulder around 2281 cm-1. The ratio between these two bands is nearly constant for the whole series. The shoulder can then be assigned to a different Lewis site indicating that acetonitrile may interact with Y in different ways. The adsorbed acetonitrile remains in the structure after outgassing at RT. A complete desorption can be obtained by heating to 80 °C.

elements.content: 5.4. XANES and EXAFS. No significant change is observed in the Pt L3-edge EXAFS signal upon dehydration, rehydration, or interaction with CH3CN with CH3OH, see Figure . The only, minor, changes concern the weak Pt−C contributions centered around 2.5 Å in the phase-uncorrected FTs reported in Figure , indicating that the adsorbed molecules slightly perturb the organic part of the MOF. The same holds for the XANES spectrum. On the quantitative ground, the fit of the corresponding EXAFS spectra resulted in Pt−N and Pt−Cl parameters compatible with those obtained for the as synthesized material (see Table S1 of the Supporting Information), showing that the investigated probe molecules are not able to enter the first coordination shell of the Pt centers.

A different behavior has been observed for the Y local environment. Water removal causes a substantial decrease of the first-shell Y−O contribution accompanied by a shift toward lower R values (compare the black and gray full lines in Figure a). Simultaneously, in the XANES spectra, Figure b, a decrease of the white line intensity (first resonance after the edge) is observed, reflecting a reduction in the number of ligands. The first-shell data analysis resulted in a decrease of N Y - O from 8.1 ± 1.0 to 7.1 ± 1.0 (Table ). The single-crystal XRD study indicates that, beside water molecules, Y is coordinated to five O ligands. The coordination number found by EXAFS for the dehydrated material (N Y - O = 7.1 ± 1.0), accompanied by the observation of a complete removal of the three water molecules coordinated to each Y cation (TGA measurements, Figure ), suggest that some oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units should have modified their position to partially substitute the water molecules in the Y first coordination shell. Note that, in the as-prepared material, not all the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units interact directly with the Y cations. This important effect, highlighted by EXAFS spectroscopy, is able to explain (i) the modification of the long-range order observed by XRPD during the dehydration experiment (Figure ) as well as the pulverization of the single crystal, (ii) the differences in the framework vibration modes observed between as-prepared and rehydrated material (compare the bold black and gray curves in Figure ), and (iii) the modification of the Pt−C contributions in the FT of the Pt L3-edge EXAFS spectra (Figure ). In the dehydration process R Y - O reduces from 2.32 ± 0.03 to 2.29 ± 0.03 (Table ).

elements.content: A novel Pt/Y-metal−organic framework has been synthesized; its structure has been solved by single-crystal XRD and its adsorptive, vibrational, and electronic properties have been characterized with several techniques. The main building block, consisting of Pt(II) cis-coordinated to BPDC, has been designed to closely resembles the catalytically active sites in homogeneous counterparts developed for C−H activation. These units are further connected through Y ions, resulting in an extended framework stable up to 400 °C, a result representing an improvement in stability of 50 °C compared to that of the previously synthesized isostructural Pt/Gd-MOF.
elements.clean_text:
6. Conclusion

A novel Pt/Y-metal-organic framework has been synthesized; its structure has been solved by single-crystal XRD and its adsorptive, vibrational, and electronic properties have been characterized with several techniques. The main building block, consisting of Pt(II) cis-coordinated to BPDC, has been designed to closely resembles the catalytically active sites in homogeneous counterparts developed for C-H activation. These units are further connected through Y ions, resulting in an extended framework stable up to 400 °C, a result representing an improvement in stability of 50 °C compared to that of the previously synthesized isostructural Pt/Gd-MOF.

elements.content: The internal void of the Pt/Y−organic framework after removal of the solvent is shown to be accessible by water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile. The estimated volume occupied by the probe molecules is significant, implying that the probe molecules are filling the pores. The percentage of filling depends on the physical size and the flexibility of the probe molecules. Small molecule, like water, can recover more than 90% of the initial volume occupied by the crystal water. Larger or more rigid probe molecules such as ethanol and acetonitrile are only able to fill around 60% of the initial volume.

elements.content: The vibration properties of the compound are closely related to presence of water in the structure. Water is strongly perturbed in the as-synthesized phase. The vibration properties are less affected by the presence of methanol or acetonitrile. Filling the pores give systematic shift of some bands caused by ligand deformations. Probing with acetonitrile indicates clearly that Lewis acid sites are accessible. EXAFS and XANES data, collected at both Pt L3-and Y K-edges, indicate that adsorbed molecules are able to directly enter the first coordination shell of Y. Interaction with the Pt local environment occurs only by a perturbation of the Pt−C contributions at 2.9−3.0 Å. Results obtained from TPA/TPD, UV−vis, FTIR, EXAFS, and XANES are in agreement and confirmed that the internal void of the material is accessible by several probe molecules after removal of the solvent.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF in N2 was followed by TGA, and the profile is presented in Figure . Besides a weight loss of 9.41 wt % in the first one-hundred degrees, we observe a wide plateau ranging up to 450 °C. This weight loss matches closely the number of 11 water molecules, corresponding to a weight percent of 10.43, refined in the single-crystal XRD study (section 3.1). The chemical nature of the desorbed molecules was checked in a parallel experiment, where we analyzed the effluent as a function of temperature finding that the first weight loss represents water desorption. Temperature-resolved XRPD confirmed the presence of a crystalline phase in the 110−400 °C plateau, see the black patterns in Figure . Combined XRPD and TGA reveal that the crystalline phase is stable up to 400 °C, while an amorphization process occurs in the 400−450 °C range without decomposition, that starts from 450 °C. The improved thermal stability of the Pt/Y-MOF compared to that of the Pt/Gd-MOF analogue22 (400 vs 350 °C) represents an advantage for any possible application of the material.

At temperatures higher than 450 °C, XRPD of the residue (gray curves in Figure ) confirms the complete decomposition of the MOF structure to elemental Pt and Y2O3. The weight loss in the 450−650 °C range corresponds to 44.28 wt %, see Figure . Note that the weight fraction of the organic part of the MOF material obtained from the single-crystal XRD data (section 3.1) is 46.82wt %.

5.2. DR UV − Vis − NIR Spectroscopy. The UV−vis spectrum of as-prepared Pt/Y-MOF sample (bold black curve in Figure a) is dominated by a band centered at 29 200 cm-1, caused by the intense π → π* transition of the aromatic rings. A relatively broad band located at 25 300 cm-1 can be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) from Pt to bipyridine. The edge in the visible region (at 19 100 cm-1) can be associated to Cl to Pt ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Electronic transitions related to Y are expected at higher energies, where the spectra have not been reported owing to a too poor S/N ratio.

The reported values are averaged over the three crystallographically independent Pt sites (Figures  and ). The rather low distribution of distances in the three Pt sites (Table ) results in a high-quality fit (Figure , second from top). The experimental signal of the Y K-edge has been optimized using a unique Y−O contribution. All corresponding parameters consequently have an average character. The large values of the optimized Debye−Waller factor reflect the heterogeneities of the Y−O distances (in the 2.225−2.492 Å range, see Table ) and have no dynamical meaning. The parameters that have been fixed in the fit have no corresponding error bars.

cln_elements.content: TPA/TPD experiments of water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile on Pt/Y-MOF, parts a−d, respectively. Both temperature (gray line, right ordinate axis) and weight variation (black line, left ordinate axis) profiles are reported. Each experiment has been performed in three steps defined on top of each part. (1) The sample drying by heating to 185 °C (10 °C/min), followed by an isotherm period of ≈15 min before cooling down to 25 °C. (2) Probe molecules dosage at 25 °C. This step ends when a stationary weight has been reached. (3) Molecule desorption by heating to 185 °C (10 °C/min).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  TPA/TPD experiments of water, methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile on Pt/Y-MOF, parts a-d, respectively. Both temperature (gray line, right ordinate axis) and weight variation (black line, left ordinate axis) profiles are reported. Each experiment has been performed in three steps defined on top of each part. (1) The sample drying by heating to 185 °C (10 °C/min), followed by an isotherm period of ~15 min before cooling down to 25 °C. (2) Probe molecules dosage at 25 °C. This step ends when a stationary weight has been reached. (3) Molecule desorption by heating to 185 °C (10 °C/min).

cln_elements.content: Room temperature dehydration process of Pt/Y-MOF followed by UV−vis−NIR DRS spectroscopy:  as-synthesized material (bold black curve), after increasing dehydration times (thin solid curves) up to 4 h (dotted curve) in dynamical vacuum of 10-3 torr. The spectrum obtained after rehydration is reported as a full gray curve. According to the TPA experiment of water readsorption into Pt/Y-MOF (region 2 of Figure a), the gray spectrum has been collected 4 h after water contact. Parts a and b refer to the UV−vis and NIR regions of the spectra, respectively. In the inset of part a, only the spectra of the original, the fully dehydrated, and the rehydrated Pt/Y-MOF have been reported to better appreciate the reversibility of the process.

metadata.title:
A Thermally Stable Pt/Y-Based Metal−Organic Framework:  Exploring the Accessibility of
the Metal Centers with Spectroscopic Methods Using H2O, CH3OH, and CH3CN as Probes
